“Could you ever rob and murder?” Razumihin asked, laughing silently.

Raskolnikov’s eyes narrowed. 

“If I did, I wouldn’t tell you.”

Razumihin shifted, intrigued. 

“Don’t we all think ourselves Napoleons now?” Porfiry added, tone unsettling.

Raskolnikov felt repulsion. 

“I’m no Mahomet or Napoleon,” he replied coldly.

Zametov blurted, “Perhaps a future Napoleon killed Alyona Ivanovna last week?”

Silence fell. Raskolnikov turned, anger simmering.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov grapples with the idea of whether extraordinary individuals can justify committing crimes for a greater purpose.
